hobby.message: Still chasing ghosts with analog photography?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: No problems getting here. Building’s quieter tonight.
I do origami, in case you didn’t know.
Sometimes I fold at the bar, sometimes at home.
Lot of changes lately, so hobbies help, I suppose.
No, it was fine. Common spaces feel less tense now.
I brought some scrap paper with me. I fold origami models.
Makes waiting easier, especially on uncertain days.
My building’s been different since all these assemblies.
Hard to focus, but folding helps me tune out the noise.
Not much trouble. Hallways are pretty busy now since the rules shifted.
I spent some time folding origami before I came.
Mostly modular stars or tessellations—still have a stack of old transit passes.
Unusual how quiet things used to be. Now, I work on pieces with more people around.
I used to fold alone. Now it doesn’t feel so odd if someone watches.
Sometimes I lose track of time and miss the news happening outside.
No trouble at all. It’s almost lively around here again, isn’t it?
I actually stayed in the corridor a bit, folding origami with a neighbor.
Never thought I’d teach someone else how to do a Kawasaki rose, but—here we are.
I use whatever scrap I find: system notices, receipts, even old sanctions letters.
A few weeks ago, I’d have hidden hobby stuff if anyone passed by.
Since the assemblies started, people keep asking what I’m making.
It feels strange to share something so private now.
Getting here was easy. My building’s like a little commons lately. Completely new feeling.
I kept folding origami in the corridor tonight—used to hide it, honestly.
Origami is my reset button. I learned as a kid, kept adding complexity to keep sane.
Now I use old system forms—the ironies aren’t lost on me.
Neighbors used to ignore me. Now, since the ghosts reappeared, they want to join in.
After the data leaks, folding became how I ground myself after long shifts.
At last week’s assembly, I gave away a few modular pieces as icebreakers.
Funny how freedom is unsettling. Folding paper still makes sense even when nothing else does.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still folding. Keeps my hands busy, you know.
Lately it feels...different, with everyone coming out.
The corridors don't stay quiet anymore. Makes it tough to focus.
Anyway, it's just paper. Nothing important.
Don't know how long that will last.
Still at it. Origami is better than staring at walls.
The new assemblies make things chaotic now.
More people around means more noise, less privacy for folding.
I try to keep to small models, easier to hide if someone comes.
Hard to say if it's safer now. Everything feels exposed.
I just stick to what I know.
Yeah, still folding origami. Helps me think through messier things.
Since the elections, neighbors I never saw are everywhere.
I used to have a routine: alone, quiet, one model a night.
Now I get interrupted. Sometimes people want to watch or join in.
Paper's harder to come by, too. Everyone saving documents.
I fold modular stars—they take patience. Distraction helps with the noise.
Feels like folding pieces of the old city, bit by bit.
Always. I fold even when my hands shake.
After the ghost assemblies, people just started knocking, gathering in halls.
I never used to fold in public but now...sometimes I bring it with me.
Paper scraps in meetings, corridor corners, even the bar—feels less suspicious than before.
Last night, folded a crane at the laundry-room assembly. Someone asked for one.
The gatherings are loud but nobody looks at me weird anymore.
I notice how others handle paper now. Secret notes. Voting slips folded to nothing.
Origami turned from hiding to...I guess, sharing a little hope.
Definitely still folding. It started as a nervous habit back in school.
I need order when everything else gets unpredictable. Like after the leak, I made a thousand cranes.
These days, the communal spaces are full—since all the disappeared people came back.
A few weeks ago I brought my origami to a ghost assembly, not thinking much of it.
Someone recognized a tessellation pattern from Halden's system diagrams. Suddenly, everyone wanted a piece.
We started folding together, sharing paper and secrets—bits of old memos, Council handouts.
Last night, a young kid brought me a crumpled election flyer to fold. Felt symbolic somehow.
Folding isn't just anxiety management, now. It connects people who never spoke before.
Funny, after years hiding this, it's the one thing that feels honest in public.
